required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 10, 2017
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Influence of Preoperative Vitamin B12 and Folate Administration on Homocysteine Concentrations After Nitrous Oxide Anesthesia
clinical_study.official_title: Influence of Preoperative Vitamin B12 and Folate Administration on Homocysteine Concentrations After Nitrous Oxide Anesthesia

collaborator.agency: Foundation for Anesthesia Education and Research

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this study is to find out if giving intravenous B-vitamins before general anesthesia with nitrous oxide prevents the increase in homocysteine, a metabolite that has been linked to cardiovascular complications.

study_design_info.masking: Double Blind (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately postoperatively and on postoperative day 1

secondary_outcome.measure: Association of MTHFR 677C>T genotype on tHcy increase

arm_group.description: Patients receive IV B-vitamins (1mg vitamin B12 and 5 mg folic acid diluted in 250 ml normal saline infusion) plus 60% nitrous oxide anesthesia
Patients receive placebo (250 ml normal saline infusion) plus 60% nitrous oxide anesthesia
Patients receive placebo (250 ml normal saline infusion) but NO nitrous oxide (60% air and oxygen mix).

intervention.description: IV vitamin B12 (cyanocobalamin) 1 mg, single administration over 30 min. IV folic acid, 5 mg, single administration over 30 min. Both diluted in 250 ml normal saline.
Placebo: only 250 ml normal saline, no B-vitamins
NO nitrous oxide (60% air and oxygen mix).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients scheduled for elective surgery with expected duration > 2 hours
- Healthy patients undergoing moderate surgery where the use of N2O is unproblematic
Exclusion Criteria:
- Contraindication against N2O (pneumothorax, mechanical bowel obstruction, middle ear occlusion, laparoscopic surgery, raised intracranial pressure)
- Patients requiring supplemental oxygen
- Urgent or emergent surgery
- Patients with vitamin B12 or folate deficiency or megaloblastic anemia
- Patients with seizure disorder (epilepsy)
- Allergy or hypersensitivity against IV cobalamin or folate
- Patients with Leber's disease (hereditary optic nerve atrophy)
- Patients taking supplemental vitamin B12 or folate

reference.citation: Nagele P, Zeugswetter B, Wiener C, Burger H, Hüpfl M, Mittlböck M, Födinger M. Influence of methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase gene polymorphisms on homocysteine concentrations after nitrous oxide anesthesia. Anesthesiology. 2008 Jul;109(1):36-43. doi: 10.1097/ALN.0b013e318178820b.

Nagele P, Zeugswetter B, Eberle C, Hüpfl M, Mittlböck M, Födinger M. A common gene variant in methionine synthase reductase is not associated with peak homocysteine concentrations after nitrous oxide anesthesia. Pharmacogenet Genomics. 2009 May;19(5):325-9. doi: 10.1097/FPC.0b013e328328d54c.

Myles PS, Chan MT, Kaye DM, McIlroy DR, Lau CW, Symons JA, Chen S. Effect of nitrous oxide anesthesia on plasma homocysteine and endothelial function. Anesthesiology. 2008 Oct;109(4):657-63. doi: 10.1097/ALN.0b013e31818629db.

clinical_study.keyword: Focus is on all patients receiving general anesthesia with nitrous oxide for elective surgery
